results.content: One of the minor complaints that stood out is the presenters reliance on /deep/, (::ng-deep , >>>) in CSS.  Deep styling will not be supported by Angular in future state and currently gets flagged in code quality software checks making it impossible to use in many professional situations.  Would have liked to hear a more detail/explanation on alternative solutions during the course

results.content: Informative course, but many cases of mismatch of the code in the lecture with the code of a student resulting from progressing throughout the course. Similar bugs are numerous spread around the course.

results.content:
I'd not recommend buying this course, it is not Advanced level and outdated contains invalid code (which is not allowed to use now, deprecated). What is more, the author does not answer questions and the course description is misleading.
Details: according to the description, the course is updated in the current month, but it is not true, it is for very old Angular v7 (whereas Angular 11 is now and 12 is coming). Deprecated things are mentioned and invalid to use, no updates. What is more, I would not agree that it is Advanced, you would better read the official documentation. E.g. the author manipulates DOM as not recommended by Angular at all, we need to use Rendere2 and not direct dom manipulation (where you assign value to nativeElement directly, for example). Another example - he uses 'keyCode' for Keyboard event, you can check MDN ''Avoid using it, and update existing code if possible". I can provide more examples.
 I see questions from different students but without answers (although months passed), I got only 1 answer for my questions.
results.content_html:
I'd not recommend buying this course, it is not Advanced level and outdated contains invalid code (which is not allowed to use now, deprecated). What is more, the author does not answer questions and the course description is misleading.

Deprecated things are mentioned and invalid to use, no updates. What is more, I would not agree that it is Advanced, you would better read the official documentation. E.g. the author manipulates DOM as not recommended by Angular at all, we need to use Rendere2 and not direct dom manipulation (where you assign value to nativeElement directly, for example). Another example - he uses 'keyCode' for Keyboard event, you can check MDN ''Avoid using it, and update existing code if possible". I can provide more examples.
I see questions from different students but without answers (although months passed), I got only 1 answer for my questions.

results.content:
This is one of the best courses containing real-world applications. It made me painfully aware how much I duplicate code and functionality! 

Even though I was already fluent in many of the techniques used in the course, I did find the pace somewhat fast and will need to watch the course a couple more times to fully grasp each concept.

Thank you, Vasco, for a course that will definitely help me to become a better Angular developer! I look forward to taking some of your other courses.

results.content:
Great course - very important component structures explained as well as important and popular use cases - like customizing input behavior. 
The only thing I disliked was that at the start and end of almost every lesson there is too much introduction on what we are going to do next. I prefer the step by step approach rather to listening what is going to come up next upfront in great detail before it actually does come up.
Thank you for the course, learned a lot from it!

In all, I recommend the course to users seeking advance Angular skills.

results.content:
Excellent course, like all other Angular University courses.

This course gradually evolves toward more advanced concepts and features of Angular.

Being a junior-intermediate level developer, I even learned some programming patterns and approaches to common challenges that are applicable outside of Angular.  Always a bonus.

Angular being an advanced framework, a course on advanced topics could have been made much longer but at some point it would be too much.  I view this course more as a "concise introduction to advanced Angular topics" than a MasterClass.  A complete MasterClass would just be way too long.  This course gives you a good glimpse of all the power that is made available to you as a developer through the sheer amount of built-in features.  Then, you will have plenty of concepts to implement with real coding and continue evolving.

Something that I always look for in courses like this one is answers to the WHY of using some features of a framework instead of using more traditional approaches (for example, WHY should you use features of the Angular Animations Module instead of regular CSS Animations?).  Vasco (the instructor) provides answers to these types of questions most of the time.  But I think instructors in general should provide more answers, more often, to these interrogations that you have all the time as a developer when you have multiple technologies that could accomplish the same task.  Because a framework as a feature for something doesn't mean it's the BEST way to accomplish that task.  This is always tricky with the new and shiny technologies, and I would like to hear more opinions from the instructors in advanced courses.  But others could find that it's bloating the course...  So it's more of a personal wish than a criticism.

All in all, an amazing course with a great instructor!
results.content_html:
Excellent course, like all other Angular University courses.

This course gradually evolves toward more advanced concepts and features of Angular.

Being a junior-intermediate level developer, I even learned some programming patterns and approaches to common challenges that are applicable outside of Angular. Always a bonus.

Angular being an advanced framework, a course on advanced topics could have been made much longer but at some point it would be too much. I view this course more as a "concise introduction to advanced Angular topics" than a MasterClass. A complete MasterClass would just be way too long. This course gives you a good glimpse of all the power that is made available to you as a developer through the sheer amount of built-in features. Then, you will have plenty of concepts to implement with real coding and continue evolving.

Something that I always look for in courses like this one is answers to the WHY of using some features of a framework instead of using more traditional approaches (for example, WHY should you use features of the Angular Animations Module instead of regular CSS Animations?). Vasco (the instructor) provides answers to these types of questions most of the time. But I think instructors in general should provide more answers, more often, to these interrogations that you have all the time as a developer when you have multiple technologies that could accomplish the same task. Because a framework as a feature for something doesn't mean it's the BEST way to accomplish that task. This is always tricky with the new and shiny technologies, and I would like to hear more opinions from the instructors in advanced courses. But others could find that it's bloating the course... So it's more of a personal wish than a criticism.

All in all, an amazing course with a great instructor!

results.content:
It's an awesome course. It teach what you need. But I think there is a big issue for new developers:
- MESSY/Vague Indentation. It's a BIG problem, It was a nightmare, really hard to understand and it could be even worst 'cuz new developers will learn in this messy way.
- NON well tested repos (in one case missing `node-sass` don't let you do 1 test)
- Better explanations sometimes (In a level I couldn't finished 'cuz a missed step in the explanation)

results.content:
Overall, it's a good course. The material covered here is covered much more in depth than other courses (for components, templates, etc.)

A nit pick I have is the white themed text editor. These days, instructors typically use dark themed text editors, like the default one in VS Code. It's far easier on the eyes and the color coding is usually a lot better.

I did find that Vasco went a bit too fast of a pace, where I found I had to pause and rewind quite a lot.

Sometimes tricky bits that need deeper explanations are went over too quickly... like how he did: let-tabs="tabs" on the <ng-template>. Since this was very important I had to research the "let-xyz" syntax, and found there is not much out there to explain well. Thankfully I did run into Vasco's own in-depth blog post on his website which did a good job explaining it.

This was really an advanced course with a lot of nice insights. One of the best courses I ever followed.

One small remark:
- The course needs to be updated how to create an angular npm module. The explained solution is deprecated.

Subjects I like to be added to the course:
- How to adjust the Angular Material components with maintainability in mind. At my work (and I know also other companies has the same issue) the UX/Designers come with deviations on Material Components. Add changes on these Material components becomes easy a maintenance nightmare.

results.content:
Everything about content projection, templates, containers and writing modular and re-usable components was pure gold for me at least. I have not stumbled on those concepts anywhere and was really surprised that I have missed such important part of Angular development.

I think Vasco is a great instructor. He explains complicated things in a relaxed and clear way. He appears to have a lot of experience and also seems to really know his way around Angular really well.

I bought this course hoping to find some answers for managing the development of a single Angular application across different teams and different repositories. I sort of got the answer in the "custom library" part, but did not get exactly what I was looking for.

Personally I think the input mask thing was a little out of place in this course and wasn't really Angular specific, but that part was really interesting to me anyway.

I would love to see a course/blog about developing enterprise Angular applications where different modules of the application are not part of the main application code base and are lazily loaded in the main application in build. Also, how those external modules would be developed and tested in isolation.

Great job Vasco, hoping to see more great courses from you!
results.content_html:
Everything about content projection, templates, containers and writing modular and re-usable components was pure gold for me at least. I have not stumbled on those concepts anywhere and was really surprised that I have missed such important part of Angular development.

I think Vasco is a great instructor. He explains complicated things in a relaxed and clear way. He appears to have a lot of experience and also seems to really know his way around Angular really well.

I bought this course hoping to find some answers for managing the development of a single Angular application across different teams and different repositories. I sort of got the answer in the "custom library" part, but did not get exactly what I was looking for.

Personally I think the input mask thing was a little out of place in this course and wasn't really Angular specific, but that part was really interesting to me anyway.

I would love to see a course/blog about developing enterprise Angular applications where different modules of the application are not part of the main application code base and are lazily loaded in the main application in build. Also, how those external modules would be developed and tested in isolation.

Great job Vasco, hoping to see more great courses from you!

results.content: Very impressed about the topics covered, currently is hard to find real advanced use cases of angular, normally tutorials cover only the most used features for the very common use cases, Vasco can go deep to this with a simplistic approach making the topics easy to grasp. Very excited about the course content so far!

Thanks Vasco

results.content: Excellent content and some great examples of how to build reusable angular components using some of its advanced features. Thank you for yet another great course!

results.content: Very good course overall.  There are some points where following along with the video did not lead to working code, but I could work around most of them.  I expect this is from Angular having been updated since the video was made.
results.content_html: Very good course overall. There are some points where following along with the video did not lead to working code, but I could work around most of them. I expect this is from Angular having been updated since the video was made.

results.content:
Needs diagrams etc... before and after each bit of work, as it's sometimes confusing when you are switching between files, nice to know what the layout is and what you plan to do as a picture beforehand.
Btw when pronouncing character use 'ca' and not 'char', english language is funny for all to pronounce. (ca-rek-ter, just to help you).
Excellent course, really enjoyed it !

results.content: A lot of instructional code.  It didn't seem to flow as well as other Angular University courses, seemed a bit more like copy/paste instruction.  Still, If you plan to publish your own Angular Modules or simply create Components that are reusable, this course is still worth a look.  Angular components are easy.  Reusable components can get much more complex quickly.
results.content_html: A lot of instructional code. It didn't seem to flow as well as other Angular University courses, seemed a bit more like copy/paste instruction. Still, If you plan to publish your own Angular Modules or simply create Components that are reusable, this course is still worth a look. Angular components are easy. Reusable components can get much more complex quickly.

results.content:
It is a great course for those who are already somewhat familiar with Angular already. I like the approach to show multiple solutions for the same problem and the explanation are really useful. One can also learn a lot from the problem debuggings both on HTML/CSS and Angular side.

On the downside, I would have liked to see test driven development, as Angular is a perfect fit for that, so I think it is missed opportunity.
results.content_html:

results.content: Should cover advance topics in Angular instead of focus on CSS classes
results.content_html: Should cover advance topics in Angular instead of focus on CSS classes

results.content: While the content is excellent, and the instructor is obviously very skilled at the subjects he's teaching, I do find the pacing to be unnecessarily erratic. Some explanations of relatively simple concepts is being drawn out for a very long time, and the same things is being said over and over again, while at the same time the more complex concepts are rushed through, and the coding done so fast I have to pause the videos several times during just a few seconds of video in order to catch up (and I code fairly fast myself). So much coding is being done by copy/paste from things the instructor apparently have on the ready but that we have to type out. I also get the impression a lot of the coding is not planned out ahead, so there is a lot of typing in something only to move it around and redo it completely even before ever seeing the result of the first way. It's very confusing and hard to keep up with when this happens, and unfortunately it happens a lot. I think this is the only course I've taken so far where I have a pretty equal need for the increased speed, fast forward, and pause functions.
results.content_html: While the content is excellent, and the instructor is obviously very skilled at the subjects he's teaching, I do find the pacing to be unnecessarily erratic. Some explanations of relatively simple concepts is being drawn out for a very long time, and the same things is being said over and over again, while at the same time the more complex concepts are rushed through, and the coding done so fast I have to pause the videos several times during just a few seconds of video in order to catch up (and I code fairly fast myself). So much coding is being done by copy/paste from things the instructor apparently have on the ready but that we have to type out. I also get the impression a lot of the coding is not planned out ahead, so there is a lot of typing in something only to move it around and redo it completely even before ever seeing the result of the first way. It's very confusing and hard to keep up with when this happens, and unfortunately it happens a lot. I think this is the only course I've taken so far where I have a pretty equal need for the increased speed, fast forward, and pause functions.

results.content:
Section 1 was great - good explanations, more straight-to-the-point, interesting and the subject isn't really smth you can easily find in the most of the lessons, courses and articles in the internet. 

But section 2 is a disappointment. First of all the angular-quickstart-lib doesn't seem to work anymore and there is no information of how to apply it to your library. Second fail is that the section doesn't include any information of how to transform and structure your library to match the Angular Package Format v4.0. The section overall is crumpled and I don't understand why the necessary information wasn't provided by instructor, so minus 2 stars for that...
results.content_html:
Section 1 was great - good explanations, more straight-to-the-point, interesting and the subject isn't really smth you can easily find in the most of the lessons, courses and articles in the internet.

But section 2 is a disappointment. First of all the angular-quickstart-lib doesn't seem to work anymore and there is no information of how to apply it to your library. Second fail is that the section doesn't include any information of how to transform and structure your library to match the Angular Package Format v4.0. The section overall is crumpled and I don't understand why the necessary information wasn't provided by instructor, so minus 2 stars for that...
